hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: Puali‘i taught the ko‘ilipi, and they went to the place of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, where they found the eight seas, on the fire. All the children knew, and they stood at a resting place for the eyes of Puali‘i. Puali‘i spoke to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Behold! This ko‘ilipi in my hand, it is a thing of the night for the time of this day, and the night of the moon, and then, the canoe with the fish, and the food for me first, and then, peace.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not understand these words of Puali‘i, and then, the words of Puali‘i were new, it was the two. Puali‘i was careful to interpret to Nāmakaokapāo‘o the ko‘ilipi, in that time to pray for Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s prayer of peace for Puali‘i. Thus the prayer: “Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, O you who are the guardian of my sacred place, O you who are the guardian of the sea, O you who are the guardian of the moon, O you who are the guardian of the heavens, O Kukui‘aimakaokalani, O my sacred place here, O Nāmakaokai‘a the great chief of Hawai‘i, O you who are silent, O you who are still, O the people, O the sacred, O the sacred, peace only to Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary:
• The passage reflects a ritualistic exchange between Puali‘i and Nāmakaokapāo‘o, symbolizing the transmission of sacred knowledge and the negotiation of power in a pre-contact Hawaiian society  
  – The term *ko‘ilipi* (possibly a sacred object or chant) represents the concealment of knowledge, a common motif in Hawaiian narratives where wisdom is guarded or encoded  
  – The "eight seas" (*e ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā*) may allegorically reference the eight regions of Hawai‘i or the four cardinal directions multiplied by two (symbolizing balance), aligning with traditional cosmology where the ocean embodies both life and the unknown  
  – The phrase *pule make* (prayer of peace) underscores the spiritual and political significance of *kīke‘i* (sacredness) in Hawaiian governance  

• Analysis of names and symbolism  
  – *Puali‘i*: From *pau* (complete) and *li‘i* (to measure or judge), suggesting a figure of authority or a leader who "measures" or "judges" the people  
  – *Nāmakaokapāo‘o*: *Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o* (Sea of the pāo‘o), where *pāo‘o* (a type of fish or a term for "to be silent") may symbolize the ocean’s role as a boundary between worlds or a source of sustenance  
  – *Kukui‘aimakaokalani*: *Kukui* (light, deity of fire), *aimaka* (sacred), *okalani* (heavens), suggesting a divine protector of sacred knowledge or a celestial guide  
  – *Kālua me ka ‘uala* (canoe with fish) symbolizes survival and resourcefulness, a metaphor for the *mo‘olelo* (stories) that sustain cultural memory  

• Historical and cultural context  
  – The reference to *Ai Kapu era* (the kapu system) is implicit in the sacredness of *ko‘ilipi* and *pule make*, reflecting the pre-contact religious hierarchy where knowledge was guarded by *kūpuna* (elders) and *kahu‘aina* (land stewards)  
  – The phrase *i luna o ke ahi* (on the fire) may allude to the 1819 abolition of the kapu system, where fire symbolized the destruction of old rituals and the rise of new social orders  
  – The prayer’s structure mirrors *mele* (hymns) used in *ho‘okupu* (rituals) to invoke deities, blending pre-contact spirituality with later Christian influences (post-1820 missionary era) in the preservation of oral traditions  

• Numerical symbolism and riddles  
  – *E ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā* (eight seas) may encode the eight *māku‘u* (regions) of Hawai‘i, emphasizing the interconnectedness of land and ocean in Hawaiian cosmology  
  – *Lua* (two) in *‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia* (the words of Puali‘i were new, it was the two) could signify the duality of *mo‘okū‘auhau* (genealogical lineage) or the balance between *moana* (ocean) and *āina* (land) in Hawaiian philosophy  

• Social commentary  
  – The tension between Puali‘i’s "new" words (*‘ōlelo hou*) and Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s lack of understanding critiques the erosion of traditional knowledge during colonialism, where *kūpuna* were marginalized by foreign influences  
  – The invocation of *Kukui‘aimakaokalani* (divine light of the sacred heavens) may allegorically represent the clash between indigenous spirituality and missionary-driven Christianity, with *kū* (to stand) symbolizing resistance to cultural assimilation  
  – The phrase *e he‘e ka hōhē wale* (to be silent as the hōhē) echoes the *ho‘oponopono‘ī* (restoring balance) process, suggesting a call for harmony amid conflict.
raw_response:
<translation>  
Puali‘i taught the ko‘ilipi, and they went to the place of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, where they found the eight seas, on the fire. All the children knew, and they stood at a resting place for the eyes of Puali‘i. Puali‘i spoke to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Behold! This ko‘ilipi in my hand, it is a thing of the night for the time of this day, and the night of the moon, and then, the canoe with the fish, and the food for me first, and then, peace.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not understand these words of Puali‘i, and then, the words of Puali‘i were new, it was the two. Puali‘i was careful to interpret to Nāmakaokapāo‘o the ko‘ilipi, in that time to pray for Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s prayer of peace for Puali‘i. Thus the prayer: “Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, O you who are the guardian of my sacred place, O you who are the guardian of the sea, O you who are the guardian of the moon, O you who are the guardian of the heavens, O Kukui‘aimakaokalani, O my sacred place here, O Nāmakaokai‘a the great chief of Hawai‘i, O you who are silent, O you who are still, O the people, O the sacred, O the sacred, peace only to Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  
</translation>  

<commentary>  
• The passage reflects a ritualistic exchange between Puali‘i and Nāmakaokapāo‘o, symbolizing the transmission of sacred knowledge and the negotiation of power in a pre-contact Hawaiian society  
  – The term *ko‘ilipi* (possibly a sacred object or chant) represents the concealment of knowledge, a common motif in Hawaiian narratives where wisdom is guarded or encoded  
  – The "eight seas" (*e ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā*) may allegorically reference the eight regions of Hawai‘i or the four cardinal directions multiplied by two (symbolizing balance), aligning with traditional cosmology where the ocean embodies both life and the unknown  
  – The phrase *pule make* (prayer of peace) underscores the spiritual and political significance of *kīke‘i* (sacredness) in Hawaiian governance  

• Analysis of names and symbolism  
  – *Puali‘i*: From *pau* (complete) and *li‘i* (to measure or judge), suggesting a figure of authority or a leader who "measures" or "judges" the people  
  – *Nāmakaokapāo‘o*: *Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o* (Sea of the pāo‘o), where *pāo‘o* (a type of fish or a term for "to be silent") may symbolize the ocean’s role as a boundary between worlds or a source of sustenance  
  – *Kukui‘aimakaokalani*: *Kukui* (light, deity of fire), *aimaka* (sacred), *okalani* (heavens), suggesting a divine protector of sacred knowledge or a celestial guide  
  – *Kālua me ka ‘uala* (canoe with fish) symbolizes survival and resourcefulness, a metaphor for the *mo‘olelo* (stories) that sustain cultural memory  

• Historical and cultural context  
  – The reference to *Ai Kapu era* (the kapu system) is implicit in the sacredness of *ko‘ilipi* and *pule make*, reflecting the pre-contact religious hierarchy where knowledge was guarded by *kūpuna* (elders) and *kahu‘aina* (land stewards)  
  – The phrase *i luna o ke ahi* (on the fire) may allude to the 1819 abolition of the kapu system, where fire symbolized the destruction of old rituals and the rise of new social orders  
  – The prayer’s structure mirrors *mele* (hymns) used in *ho‘okupu* (rituals) to invoke deities, blending pre-contact spirituality with later Christian influences (post-1820 missionary era) in the preservation of oral traditions  

• Numerical symbolism and riddles  
  – *E ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā* (eight seas) may encode the eight *māku‘u* (regions) of Hawai‘i, emphasizing the interconnectedness of land and ocean in Hawaiian cosmology  
  – *Lua* (two) in *‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia* (the words of Puali‘i were new, it was the two) could signify the duality of *mo‘okū‘auhau* (genealogical lineage) or the balance between *moana* (ocean) and *āina* (land) in Hawaiian philosophy  

• Social commentary  
  – The tension between Puali‘i’s "new" words (*‘ōlelo hou*) and Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s lack of understanding critiques the erosion of traditional knowledge during colonialism, where *kūpuna* were marginalized by foreign influences  
  – The invocation of *Kukui‘aimakaokalani* (divine light of the sacred heavens) may allegorically represent the clash between indigenous spirituality and missionary-driven Christianity, with *kū* (to stand) symbolizing resistance to cultural assimilation  
  – The phrase *e he‘e ka hōhē wale* (to be silent as the hōhē) echoes the *ho‘oponopono‘ī* (restoring balance) process, suggesting a call for harmony amid conflict.  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
